results.title: Rosalie Kunoth-Monks
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian biography”.
Rosalie Kunoth-Monks: Aboriginal activist, actor, social worker, Parliamentary Candidate 1979-1981, President Aboriginal Legal Aid NT 1983-87, 1990-93, was born in Utopia, Central Australia, 1937 and is of German Aboriginal parentage. Kunoth-Monks discusses her education at St Mary’s Children’s Hostel, Alice Springs, and on being discovered by Charles and Elsa Chauvel as the lead in “Jedda”. She talks about working on the film, and her family’s response to it, in particular the sexual references. A greater passion was to help people, and Rosalie joined the Community of the Holy Name in Melbourne and was a nun for ten years, also gaining training during this period in childcare. Working as an Aboriginal liaison officer in Victoria after leaving the sisterhood, Kunoth-Monks also established the first Aboriginal Family Group home, in addition to marrying during this period. A return to Central Australia saw her working for the Country Liberal Party and being active in social welfare before she returned, full circle, to Utopia.

results.title: Monsieur Rene Magritte
results.creator_credit: Adrian Maben, Neil Mundy, Antenne-2, RM Productions and WDR
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
About the life of Belgium artist Rene Magritte, one of the most famous of all surrealists. The documentary discusses his personal life and the motivations behind his art. Obsessed with the everyday, Magritte’s practise was to reinvent the ordinary by changing the ‘viewers’ perception. “It’s not the painting that changes your perception, it’s the thoughts triggered when looking at the work that does”. As a metaphysical painter like his mentor De Chirico, Magritte sought to make reality and meaning represented as visionary not literal - it’s this legacy that is explored in this documentary.

results.title: Jackson Pollock
results.creator_credit: Kim Evans, RM Arts and South Bank Show
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
This documentary shows Jackson Pollack, the most famous twentieth century American painter, as the controversial star of the New York art scene in the forties and fifties, who founded the movement ‘Abstract Expressionism’. It is an interesting look at Pollock’s life and death through various interviews with friends, from the cowboy myth, to the drunken, fast driving masculine artist. It is a documentary as revealing and engaging as Pollock’s work itself. There is footage of the artist at work finding his own technique of dripping and splashing fluid paint onto unstretched canvas layed out on the floor. It traces his history as an artist showing his early influences of native American sandpainting to his rise as an abstract expressionist. Edited and presented by Melvyn Bragg.

results.title: Graeme Bell
results.creator_credit: Frank Heimans, Sharon Connolly and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian biography”.
Often described as the ‘father of Australian jazz’ Graeme Bell has had a sixty year love affair with music, both as a performer and a composer. Discover the story of his life, speak to the man about his passion, and hear his wonderful music.

results.title: Robert Motherwell and the New York school
results.creator_credit: Catherine Tatge, International Cultural Programming, Thirteen and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Robert Motherwell was the leading figure in the Abstract Expressionist movement in New York in the 1940’s and was to revolutionise the face of American painting. Made shortly before his death in 1991 this is director Tatge’s elegy to Motherwell, the vanguard of American modernism. Along with Arshille Gorky, William Bazeodis, Hans Hoffman, Franz Kline, William de Kooning, Barnett Newman, Jackson Pollock, Mark Rothko and David Smith, Motherwell made up what is known as “The New York school”. The journey or search in their work as artists was to make art in the U.S. that was equal to that in Europe. Within a hostile political environment and known historically as the most hated of all the art movements, the Abstract Expressionists had achieved this by the early 1950’s. With archival footage and interviews this documentary paints an inspirational portrait of a man and movement in one of the most volatile times in modern history. Juxtaposed throughout is footage of Motherwell preparing for his retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum in New York.

results.title: Francis Bacon
results.creator_credit: David Hinton, London Weekend Television and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
This seminal documentary, edited and narrated by Melvyn Bragg remains one of the ‘stand out’ documentaries that surveys the life, work and motivations of British painter, Francis Bacon, through a series of interviews. Bacon, an extraordinary man, laconically introduces the relationship between broad formalist concerns and attempts to connect with the subconscious. Bacon articulates his response to images of a distressed humanity, revealing his deep fascination with the human body and its connection with much of Bacon’s life philosophies. Gritty in content, Bacon’s paintings reveal much of the ‘violence of life and death’ but seek to describe the normality of this with controlled sense of chaos, ‘capturing the moment’.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Hinton, London Weekend Television and RM Arts

results.title: Anthony Caro
results.creator_credit: Nigel Wattis, AM Productions and LWT
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
This documentary, presented and edited by Melvyn Bragg, presents the British artist Anthony Caro, famous for his ‘revolutionary’ approach to sculpture making in the 60’s. Initially training at the Royal Academy in London as a sculptor and then under the tutelage of Henry Moore, a disillusioned Caro made a trip to New York where he befriended the famous New York art critic, Clement Greenberg. The trip was to symbolise a radical shift in Caro’s approach to his art making, earning him his revolutionary status for criticisms that his work was, ‘crude and over simplified’. The documentary discusses Caro’s philosophy and methods over the decades and follows Caro in the process of constructing a number of steel sculptures. A prodigious artist with an output of over 2,000 sculptures whose search for, ‘the fact of the work and not the form’, makes this an exciting documentary about one of the modernist greats.

A prodigious artist with an output of over 2,000 sculptures whose search for, ‘the fact of the work and not the form’, makes this an exciting documentary about one of the modernist greats.

results.title: Jasper John: ideas in paint
results.creator_credit: Rick Tejada-Flores and WHYY Inc Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Narrated by Polly Adams, this interesting documentary explores the paintings of Jasper Johns and follows his career from the 1950’s through to 1988. As one of the major forces on the American art scene, Johns rejected abstraction in favour of realism and layed the ground work for Pop Art and Minimalism. Featuring excerpts from interviews with Richard Serra, Hilton Kramer, Merce Cunningham, Frank Stella, John Cage and many other friends including his agent Leo Castelli, this documentary provides a broad overview of his career. The soundtrack includes readings from composer John Cage.

results.title: W. Eugene Smith
results.creator_credit: Gene Lasko, Kirk Morris, WES Foree, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.) and WQED
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Renowned war photographer W. Eugene Smith (1918-78) photographed the victims of war throughout his distinguished career. This is an insightful portrait of a powerful and sensitive artist who used his photographs to transmit a message against the greed, the stupidity and the intolerance that causes wars that bring cruelty and suffering to humanity.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gene Lasko, Kirk Morris, WES Foree, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.) and WQED

results.title: The story of fashion. Vol. 3: The Age of dissent
results.creator_credit: Eila Hershon, Roberta Guerra and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
In the third of this three part series, Karl Lagerfeld as presenter discusses the history of fashion in the 20th Century focussing on ‘The age of dissent’, the 60’s and beyond. Lagerfeld enlightens with commentary the archival footage of fashions from the last forty years with interviews of respected seniors of the industry such as; Ralph Lauren, Issy Miyaki, Mary Quant, Ballenciaga, John Crancher, Georgio Armani, Ralph Lauren and more. In emphasis is the shift from a controlled environment to one that defines the day of ‘anything goes’. Explored is the change in attitude toward the making, showing and promotion of fashion since the sixties, a change that has developed from social conditions and lifestyle. From the ultimate dissent of ‘Punk’ to the sleek and subtle work of Jean Muir, this program celebrates design in a time where the lines between art and fashion have blurred and an increase of cultural exchange has fashioned a diffusion of styles.
results.title_for_label: The story of fashion. Vol. 3: The Age of dissent
results.creator_credit_for_label: Eila Hershon, Roberta Guerra and RM Arts

In emphasis is the shift from a controlled environment to one that defines the day of ‘anything goes’. Explored is the change in attitude toward the making, showing and promotion of fashion since the sixties, a change that has developed from social conditions and lifestyle. From the ultimate dissent of ‘Punk’ to the sleek and subtle work of Jean Muir, this program celebrates design in a time where the lines between art and fashion have blurred and an increase of cultural exchange has fashioned a diffusion of styles.
description_for_label:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
In the third of this three part series, Karl Lagerfeld as presenter discusses the history of fashion in the 20th Century focussing on ‘The age of dissent’, the 60’s and beyond. Lagerfeld enlightens with commentary the archival footage of fashions from the last forty years with interviews of respected seniors of the industry such as; Ralph Lauren, Issy Miyaki, Mary Quant, Ballenciaga, John Crancher, Georgio Armani, Ralph Lauren and more. In emphasis is the shift from a controlled environment to one that defines the day of ‘anything goes’. Explored is the change in attitude toward the making, showing and promotion of fashion since the sixties, a change that has developed from social conditions and lifestyle. From the ultimate dissent of ‘Punk’ to the sleek and subtle work of Jean Muir, this program celebrates design in a time where the lines between art and fashion have blurred and an increase of cultural exchange has fashioned a diffusion of styles.
